1509035.title: Broadway - Dey Street, southwest corner
1509035.folder: Broadway - Dey Street, southwest corner, Manhattan, NY

717088f-c.title: Manhattan: Broadway - John Street
717088f-c.text:
(1)
Broadway, east side, north from but not including John Street to
Park Row. On the extreme left, appears the United States Post Office,
with the 25-story St. Paul building and the 7-storg, ornate, Chase
National Building (National Park Branch) preceding.
December 27, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONe.
(2)
A portion of the view shown in No. 1, in a southward direction.
On the extreme left, appears a portion of the Chase National Bank, with
the 6-story United Building adjoining (N.E. corner of Fulton Street).
December 27, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
A view of the stores in the 10-story building, No. 204-210 Broadway,
at the S.E. corner of Fulton Street. This property has been leased for
21 years. The present structure is to be demolished and a 2-story
building constructed on its site.
December 27, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
No. 204-21O Broadway (also No. 156 Fulton Street), the building
to be razed is the former home of the Evening Post. This structure
shown was one of the first large office buildings to be erected in
New York. For a further account and a picture of same, see Kings
Hand book of New York 1892 page 567.

717080f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Dey Street
717080f-a.text:
191-189 A 187 Broadway, at and adjoining the S. W. corner of Dey Street.
Shown on the right is a vacant lot, which on the 1922 Bromley Map of New
York City is occupied by the 15 story Gillespie Building, No. 5 Dey St.
Gift of E. M. Jenks  Prior to 1916
MAY BE REPRODUCED

717083f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Dey Street
717083f-b.text:
195 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Dey Street (left) showing the
11-story Western Union Building under demolition. Upon this site, in
conjunction with three additional plots numbered 14, 16 and 18 Dey
Street, will rise the new 28-story Western Union Building. On Dey Street
appears an extensive view westward from Broadway to the North (Hudson)
River. The tower appearing on the right is atop the Mail and Exptess
Building. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
1913.
F. M. Demarest.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.
